Literature Review: Self-propulsion of chemically active droplets has garnered significant attention in recent years due to their unique ability to swim autonomously in viscous flows. This phenomenon is attributed to the nonlinear coupling of solute transport with self-generated Marangoni flows, which is responsible for secondary transitions to more complex individual and collective dynamics. In this review, we will discuss the most recent and significant developments in the field of self-propulsion of chemically active droplets, focusing on mathematical and physical modeling, experimental design, and characterization.
